text.*:
This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (May 2018) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

A timeline of notable events relating to BBC Radio 5 Live, and its predecessor BBC Radio 5.

Radio 5[edit]

1990

  • 27 August – BBC Radio 5 launches at 9am on the old Radio 2 mediumwave frequency. The station is on air from 6am until just after midnight but only broadcasts its own programmes at peak times and weeknight evenings. The rest of its airtime is taken up with programmes from the World Service and simulcasts of the BBC’s other national stations during off-peak hours.

1991

  • 17 January – 2 March – Radio 4 News FM, the first rolling BBC radio news service is on air during the first Gulf War.[1][2] The service is deemed to be so successful that bosses began looking at ways to launch a full time news radio station.
  • 2 September – Radio 5 launches a weekday lunchtime programme in conjunction with forces station BFBS. Called BFBS Worldwide, the programme continues to be broadcast until the demise of Radio 5 in 1994.[3]
  • 5 October – Football phone-in 6-0-6 is broadcast for the first time. Danny Baker is the programme’s host. The launch of this programme is part of an expansion of Radio 5's programming. Consequently, the station no longer simulcasts the BBC's other radio stations although programming from the World Service continues to be broadcast, albeit less than before.

1992

  • 10–26 June – For the first time, the BBC provides full radio coverage of an international football tournament when it broadcasts live commentary of every game of Euro 92.
  • 25 July – 9 August – Radio 5 provides full live coverage of the 1992 Summer Olympic Games. Programmes run all day, from 6.30am until 10pm. This is the first time that BBC Radio has provided full coverage of the Games.

1993

  • May – The broadcasting arrangements for Test Match Special for the 1993 cricket season see the morning play moving from BBC Radio 3 to Radio 5 – the afternoon session remained on Radio 3 although Radio 5 does provide commentary during weekday editions of Sport on 5.

1994

  • 27 March – BBC Radio 5 signs off after three and a half years on air.

Radio 5 Live[edit]

1994

  • 28 March – Jane Garvey launches BBC Radio 5 Live at 5 am.
  • 29 March – The first edition of Up All Night is broadcast.[4]

1995

  • 27 September – The BBC begins regular Digital Audio Broadcasting, initially just from the Crystal Palace transmitting station.

1996

  • Eddie Mair leaves.

1997

  • 26 May – Julian Worricker replaces John Inverdale as host of Nationwide.
  • October – Nicky Campbell joins to present the mid-morning show.

1998

  • BBC Local Radio stations start carrying 5 Live when they are not on air. Consequently, the station is heard regularly on FM for the first time, albeit only during overnight hours.
  • 22 March – 5 Live's late night news bulletin News Extra and phone-in/talk show After Hours are broadcast for the final time. The next day a new three hour late show called Late Night Live launches and Up All Night is extended to become a four-hour show.
  • 28 March – Edwina Currie joins to present the weekend late evening show, called Late Night Currie.[5]
  • 7 September – Peter Allen and Jane Garvey take over as presenters of 5 Live Drive, which replaces Nationwide as the station's teatime programme. They swap with Julian Worricker, to takes over the breakfast programme. Victoria Derbyshire joins him later in September as co-presenter.

1999

  • 26 March – Sybil Ruscoe leaves. She is replaced on the weekday afternoon show by Ian Payne.
  • 4 April – Radio 5 Live launches a new Sunday Service' of Sunday morning political news, hosted by Fi Glover.

2000

  • July – Bob Shennan replaces Roger Mosey as Controller.[6]

2001

  • 8 May – Simon Mayo joins to present the afternoon programme.[7][8]
  • July – Aasmah Mir joins on a full time basis having previously done news reading shifts as a freelance journalist.

2002

  • 2 February – BBC Radio 5 Live Sports Extra launches.

2003

  • 13 January – Nicky Campbell replaces Julian Worricker as co-host of the breakfast show[9] and Fi Glover replaces Nicky as mid-morning presenter. Julian takes on a revamped Sunday morning programme, which replaces the Sunday Service. Also, Matthew Bannister takes over the late show, replacing Fi Glover.
  • July – Julian Worricker takes over the mid-morning show from Fi Glover.
  • 10 August – Edwina Currie presents her weekend programme Late Night Currie for the final time.
  • October – The first series of Fighting Talk is broadcast.

2004

  • August – Victoria Derbyshire takes over the mid-morning show.[10]

2005

  • 16 July – Stephen Nolan joins to present the weekend late evening phone-in show.
  • 8–12 September – 5 Live devotes its daytime schedule to broadcast extensive live coverage of the deciding Ashes cricket match.[11] Normally, the station provides reports into its regular programmes.

2006

  • Sport on 5 is renamed 5 live Sport.

2007

  • 29 July – Long running obituary programme Brief Lives is broadcast for the final time.[12]
  • September – Jane Garvey leaves to become the new presenter of ‘’Woman’s Hour’’ on BBC Radio 4.
  • November – Richard Bacon returns to the station to present the late evening show.

2008

  • April – Adrian Van Klaveren replaces Bob Shennan as Controller.

2009

  • 9 January – The Midday News is broadcast for the final time.
  • 12 January – Nicky Campbell takes over the morning phone-in following its incorporation into an extended breakfast show. The mid-morning show is pushed back an hour, running from 10am until 1 pm.[13]
  • 5 September – Danny Baker begins presenting a new Saturday morning sports-based chat show. [14] he had rejoined the station a year earlier to become one of the presenters of 6-0-6.[15]
  • 18 December – Simon Mayo presents the weekday afternoon show for the final time. However he continues to present the weekly Friday afternoon show Kermode and Mayo's Film Review.

2010

  • 11 January – Tony Livesey joins to present the late evening show, replacing Richard Bacon who takes over the afternoon programme and Gabby Logan launches a new lunchtime show.[16]
  • 5 September – Long running evening news programme The Weekend News ends and is replaced by hour-long programmes, including 5 Live Investigates presented by Adrian Goldberg, Pienaar's Politics presented by John Pienaar and a new business show On the Money presented by Declan Curry.[17]

2011

  • April – Shelagh Fogarty replaces Gabby Logan as host of the lunchtime show. Also, Anna Foster replaces Rachel Burden as host of the weekend breakfast show – Rachel moves to become co-host of the weekday breakfast show from 3 May, replacing Shelagh Fogerty.[18]
  • Autumn – The station moves to MediaCity UK in Salford.[19]
  • 25 October – The BBC announces that, from next season, it will axe the second commentator for football matches as a cost-cutting measure.[20]

2012

  • 27 July-12 August – 5 Live operates a temporary station – 5 Live Olympics Extra – to provide additional coverage of the 2012 Summer Olympic Games.
  • August – The Non-League Football Show launches as a national programme, presented by Caroline Barker.[21] It had previously been broadcast on BBC Radio London since 2006.
  • 9 November – Aasmah Mir leaves. She is replaced on 5 Live Drive by Anna Foster.

2013

  • 19 February – Jonathan Wall replaces Adrian Van Klaveren as Controller.[22]
  • April – Tony Livesey becomes the weekend breakfast show host.
  • 13 May – Phil Williams takes over the weekday late evening show.
  • 6 August – BBC Radio 5 Live hires former Radio 4 newsreader Charlotte Green to read the classified football results.[23] She makes her debut on 28 September.[24]
  • 28 September – Charlotte Green reads the classified football results for the first time.[25] She replaces James Alexander Gordon who retired in July who had read the results since 1974.[26]

2014

  • 1 July – BBC Radio 5 Live announces the departure of Richard Bacon, Victoria Derbyshire and Shelagh Fogarty, who will leave when the station's schedule is overhauled in the autumn.[27]
  • 6 October – The schedule changes are rolled out. Adrian Chiles and Peter Allen take on the mid morning show, called 5 Live Daily, Dan Walker and Sarah Brett launch Afternoon Edition and Tony Livesey and Anna Foster become hosts of Drive.[28]
  • November – Emma Barnett, women's editor of The Daily Telegraph joins.[29] She presents a new Sunday evening programme called Hit List, a countdown of the 40 highest profile online news stories of the week.[30]

2015

  • 1 October – Plans to expand sister station Sports Extra are dropped for a second time over concerns over the impact it would have on commercial rivals such as TalkSPORT.[31]

2016

  • August – The Non-League Football Show ends when the BBC decides not to commission any more shows.[32]
  • September – Peter Allen and Jane Garvey are re-united to host a new Sunday evening show, Emma Barnett becomes the Wednesday to Friday host of 5 Live Daily and Nihal Arthanayake replaces Dan Walker as co-host of Afternoon Edition.[33]

2017

  • No events.

2018

  • January – Changes to the weekday mid-morning show take place. The Five Live Daily name is dropped. The Monday to Thursday editions are renamed The Emma Barnett Show to co-inside with Emma Barnett taking over the programme and Adrian Chiles hosts the Friday show which is called Chiles on Friday.
